The Model Object

Source: ../vignettes/The_Model_Object.Rmd
The_Model_Object.Rmd

The purpose of this vignette is to document the structure of a Dynamic Topmodel ‘object’; that is the structure of the model that can be generated in the dynatopGIS package and is used in calls to the dynatop function in the current package. Currently the model is stored as an R variable of the list class. In the future it is indended to create an S3 (or similar) class for the model to formalise the object oriented style adopted in the a package.

This should be read alongside the “Getting Started” vignette.

The model strucutre will be documented with reference to the model in the test catchment data supplied with the package. This can be loaded with

library(dynatop)
#> Loading required package: xts
#> Loading required package: zoo
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'zoo'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     as.Date, as.Date.numeric
#> Registered S3 method overwritten by 'xts':
#>   method     from
#>   as.zoo.xts zoo
#> Loading required package: Matrix
data("Swindale")
model <- Swindale$model

The top level of the model contains the following elements:

names(model)
#> [1] "hillslope"    "channel"      "param"        "Fsz"          "Fsf"         
#> [6] "gauge"        "point_inflow"

These are oulined in Table 1 and described in more detail in the sections below.

Table 1: Decription of top level model components
Name Class Description
hillslope data frame Description of the hill slope HRU units
channel data frame Description of the channel HRU units
Wsat matrix Fractions for the redistribution of the saturated zone fluxes between hill slope HRUs
Wex matrix Fractions for the redistribution of the surface excess fluxes between hill slope HRUs
Fsat matrix Fractions for the redistribution of the saturated zone fluxes between hill slope and channel HRUs
Fex matrix Fractions for the redistribution of the surface excess fluxes between hill slope and channel HRUs
point_inflow data frame Description of the locations of point inflows to the channel network
Fex data frame Description of the gauge locations on the channel network

Hillslope HRU table

Each row of the hillslope HRU table describes a single hillslope HRU, the input series in expects and parameters. In this example it looks like:

head(model$hillslope)
#>   id       area    atb_bar     s_bar delta_x class sz_band sf_band  precip
#> 1 20   56.79949  0.1518315 0.9588722       4    20       1       1 unknown
#> 2 21  533.07446  1.4347204 0.2355992       4    21       1       1 unknown
#> 3 22   16.00000 -0.1412616 1.5990150       4    20       2       2 unknown
#> 4 23 3169.46382  2.4856351 0.1027385       4    22       1       1 unknown
#> 5 24  176.16044  1.5823726 0.3055067       4    21       2       2 unknown
#> 6 25   32.00000  0.4395916 1.1364723       4    20       3       3 unknown
#>       pet         q_sfmax         s_rzmax         s_rz0         ln_t0         m
#> 1 unknown q_sfmax_default s_rzmax_default s_rz0_default ln_t0_default m_default
#> 2 unknown q_sfmax_default s_rzmax_default s_rz0_default ln_t0_default m_default
#> 3 unknown q_sfmax_default s_rzmax_default s_rz0_default ln_t0_default m_default
#> 4 unknown q_sfmax_default s_rzmax_default s_rz0_default ln_t0_default m_default
#> 5 unknown q_sfmax_default s_rzmax_default s_rz0_default ln_t0_default m_default
#> 6 unknown q_sfmax_default s_rzmax_default s_rz0_default ln_t0_default m_default
#>           t_d         t_sf
#> 1 t_d_default t_sf_default
#> 2 t_d_default t_sf_default
#> 3 t_d_default t_sf_default
#> 4 t_d_default t_sf_default
#> 5 t_d_default t_sf_default
#> 6 t_d_default t_sf_default

The individual columns are documented in Table 2. With the exception of the id, area, atb_bar and s_bar columns the table does not contain numeric values but the names of either time series to find in the forecing data or parameters in model$param.

Table 2: Description of hillslope data frame columns
Column Class Description
id integer Unique identifying number of the hillslope HRU. If generated by dynatopGIS this will match the identifying number in the raster map used to generate the model.
area numeric Area of the HRU in m\(^2\)
atb_bar numeric Average of upslope area divided by tan of gradient topographic index
s_bar numeric Average gradient
delta_x numeric Length of HSU
class numeric Class of HSU
sz_band numeric Computational band of the saturated zone
sf_band numeric Computational band of the surface zone
precip character Name of the input series to use for precipitation
pet character Name of the input series to use for potential evapotranspiration
q_sfmax character Maximum flow rate from surface to root zone
s_rzmax character Name of the maximum root zone depth parameter
s_rz0 character Name of the intial root zone depth parameter
ln_t0 character Name of the saturated conductivity parameter
m character Name of the exponential transmissivity constant parameter
t_d character Name of the unsaturated zone time constant per m of saturated storage deficit parameter.
t_sf character Name of the Surface excess storage time constant parameter

Channel HRU table

Each row of the channel HRU table describes a single hillslope HRU, the input series in expects and parameters. In this example it looks like:

head(model$channel)
#>   id      area length sz_band sf_band next_id  precip     pet         v_ch
#> 1  1 1734.0875    431    2754    2754      18 unknown unknown v_ch_default
#> 2  2 2052.9979    513    2754    2754      15 unknown unknown v_ch_default
#> 3  3 2957.4277    740    2754    2754      19 unknown unknown v_ch_default
#> 4  4 2298.0998    573    2754    2754       5 unknown unknown v_ch_default
#> 5  5  116.1749     29    2754    2754      17 unknown unknown v_ch_default
#> 6  6 1652.2072    413    2754    2754      16 unknown unknown v_ch_default

The individual columns are documented in Table 3. With the exception of the id, area, next_id and length the table does not contain numeric values but the names of either time series to find in the forecing data or parameters in model$param.

Table 3: Description of channel data frame columns
Column Class Description
id integer Unique identifying number of the hillslope HRU. If generated by dynatopGIS this will match the identifying number in the channel raster map used to generate the model.
area numeric Area of the HRU in m\(^2\)
length numeric Length of the channel in metres
sz_band numeric Computational band of the saturated zone
sf_band numeric Computational band of the surface zone
next_id integer The id of the next channel HRU downstream
precip character Name of the input series to use for precipitation
pet character Name of the input series to use for potential evapotranspiration
v_ch character Name of the channel velocity parameter

Parameter vector

The paraemter vector is a named numneric vector of parameter values. The names should correspond to those specified in the hillslope and channel tables. In this case:

model$param
#> q_sfmax_default s_rzmax_default   s_rz0_default   ln_t0_default       m_default 
#>             Inf           0.050           0.990          19.000           0.004 
#>     t_d_default    t_sf_default    v_ch_default 
#>          20.000         100.000         100.000

Redistribution matrices (Fsf, Fsz)

The redistributiuon matrices specify how the lateral fluxes move between the different HSUs. The matrices are specfied in the same fashion with columns being the ‘source’ HRU and rows the ‘destination’ HRU. The columns and rows are not named but are referenced via the id of the HSU as found in the id columns in the hillslope and channel tables.

In the case of Wex and Wsat which characterise the movements between the hillslope HRUs it can be seen that the names are the same in both cases:

Point Inflows

The point_inflow data frame allows the specification of locations on the river network at which inflows can occur. The strucutre of the data frame exactly matchs that of the gauge specifications (see Table 4). In the current catchment there are no inflows so the table is left blank:

model$point_inflow
#> [1] name     id       fraction
#> <0 rows> (or 0-length row.names)

Gauge locations

Gauge locations can be specified on the channel HRUs as outlined in Table 4.

Table 4: Description of gauge and point inflow data frame columns
Column Class Description
name character Unique name to idenfy the gauge. used in the channel routing to name the output.
id integer The id of the channel HRU on which the gauge is sited
fraction numeric Fraction of the length of the channel HRU (from the head) of the location of the gauge. A value of 1 corresponds to the foot on the channel HRU and 0 the head.

The current example has two gauges:

model$gauge
#>         name id fraction
#> 1 channel_18 18        1

  • Redistribution matrices (Fsf, Fsz)
